name: Cyclobutadiene

energies.comment: ANTIAROMATIC - 4 π-electrons (4n, n=1) creates destructive interference. Highly unstable, only isolated in matrix at 8K or as metal complex. Total destabilization ~200 kJ/mol from: (1) ring strain (~110 kJ/mol, less than cyclopropane), (2) antiaromatic destabilization (~90 kJ/mol from destructive π-interference). Bonds are WEAKER than naive prediction. CRITICAL TEST: If feedback loop hypothesis is correct, this should show large NEGATIVE violation similar in magnitude to benzene's positive violation.
energies.source: DFT calculations and experimental matrix isolation studies
energies.confidence_note: Lower confidence because cyclobutadiene is extremely reactive. Values from computational chemistry and low-temperature matrix isolation.

reference_energies.comment: Standard bond energies (kJ/mol) for naive calculation. Naive = 2(C=C) + 2(C-C) + 4(C-H) = 2(602) + 2(346) + 4(413) = 3548 kJ/mol

notes: Cyclobutadiene is THE canonical example of antiaromatic destabilization
4 π-electrons violates Hückel's 4n+2 rule (this is 4n where n=1)
Extremely reactive - dimerizes instantly at room temperature
Only stable at 8K in inert gas matrix or as metal-coordinated complex
Predicted violation: -150 to -200 kJ/mol (destructive interference in feedback loop)
If feedback loop hypothesis is correct: same mechanism as benzene but OPPOSITE SIGN
Bond orders shown as 1.5 represent delocalized but antiaromatic system
This tests whether cycles create correlation feedback that can be constructive OR destructive
